channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Brazil’s Senate Votes to Move Ahead With Dilma Rousseff’s Trial
item.description: With the eyes of the world on the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, senators in Brasília voted 59 to 21 in favor of trying the suspended president.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Mexico’s Richest Man Confronts a New Foe: The State That Helped Make Him Rich
item.media:description: Carlos Slim, center, arriving for a meeting in Nicaragua last year. More than half of his cellphone company’s sales now come from outside Mexico.
item.description: Carlos Slim built a business empire that has made him one of the world’s richest men. But Mexico’s leaders have been chipping away at his domain with regulations.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED, RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: U.S.-Backed Militias in Libya Claim to Retake ISIS Stronghold of Surt
item.media:description: Libyan forces allied with the U.N.-backed government fired a rocket at Islamic State fighters in Surt last week.
item.description: If confirmed, the capture of the seaside city of Surt would be a severe blow to the Islamic State’s expansion into North Africa.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘A Fire Happened in the Newborn Unit, and Your Baby Died’
item.description: It took more than an hour for firefighters to arrive at Baghdad’s Yarmouk hospital. No one could find keys to the nursery. None of the fire extinguishers worked.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN, OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and TIM ARANGO

item.title: Fighting in Aleppo Leaves 2 Million Without Water, U.N. Says
item.media:description: A man sat behind a broken window in May in a part of Aleppo, Syria, controlled by government forces. Water has been scarce in the city after pumps were damaged in fighting.
item.description: The United Nations implored all sides in the fighting to pause so that aid workers could deliver supplies and fix the water system.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Putting Politics Aside, Korean Gymnasts Pose for Olympic Selfie
item.media:description: The gymnasts Lee Eun-ju, right, of South Korea and Hong Un-jong of North Korea at the Rio Olympic Arena last week. Relations between the countries have been at a low over the North’s nuclear and missile tests.
item.description: The photograph, of Lee Eun-ju from South Korea, and Hong Un-jong from North Korea, has since been hailed as capturing the Olympic spirit.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Echoing a Film Plot, Chinese Gangs Kill Drifters in an Elaborate Mining Ruse
item.media:description: The closed iron ore mine in Shandong Province, in eastern China, where the police say a man’s murder was disguised as an accident.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: In dozens of cases, the Chinese authorities say, gangs have killed vagrants and workers far underground and used the deaths to defraud mine owners.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Australia Stops Online Collection of Census Data After Cyberattacks
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia, right, and Scott Morrison, the treasurer, in Sydney on Wednesday. “The site has not been hacked. It has not been interfered with,” Mr. Turnbull said. “Their data is safe.”
item.description: Officials said that a website where citizens could upload information had experienced four denial-of-service attacks, but that no data had been compromised.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Leaks Detail Abuse of Asylum Seekers Sent to Nauru by Australia
item.media:description: A vigil in Sydney, Australia, in May for two asylum seekers, a Somali woman and an Iranian man, who set themselves on fire on the remote Pacific island of Nauru.
item.description: Thousands of incident reports published by The Guardian amplify longstanding concerns about the conditions faced by migrants held on the island.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Putin Accuses Ukraine of Plotting Terrorist Attacks in Crimea
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers dismounting from a personnel carrier in Avdiivka, Ukraine. The town is one of the most active areas of fighting along the line of control between the Ukrainian government and Russian-backed rebels.
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.description: The claims by the Russian president, denounced as “fantasies” by his Ukrainian counterpart, raised the possibility of retaliation.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Memo From Poland: 'We Don’t Need to Be Alone’: A Political Shift Has Poland Assessing Its Values
item.media:description: Market Square in Wroclaw, Poland, one of the country’s largest old market sites.
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.description: Many Poles are questioning whether the European identity and freedom that meant so much after the fall of Communism hold the same value today.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: What in the World: A Space-Age Food Product Cultivated by the Incas
item.media:description: Ramona Bustos walking barefoot on potatoes to create chuño, a freeze-dried Andean staple, near La Paz, Bolivia, in 2013.
item.description: Astronauts need lightweight, long-lasting provisions for hazardous trips. So did the Incas, and villagers in the Andes have made their version for centuries.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: From Syrian Rubble to German Concert Halls With a Piano, a Mission and Survivor’s Guilt
item.media:description: On a street in Wiesbaden, Germany, a woman recognized Mr. Ahmad from one of his concerts.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: In a nation torn between embracing and fearing the migrants who have arrived in the past year, Aeham Ahmad has set himself the task of putting a human face on his fellow arrivals.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Brussels Airport Lifts Emergency Precautions After Bomb Scare
item.media:description: Belgian police vehicles at the Brussels airport in Zaventem, Belgium, on Wednesday.
item.description: The international airport in Zaventem, near the capital, resumed normal operations after receiving threats that bombs were on incoming planes.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Sinosphere: ‘Lethal Weapons’ for Chinese Feet, but Without a Feminist Debate
item.media:description: Heading for a subway station in Shanghai. Feminist discussions about high heels are largely absent in China.
item.description: The shoe choices of Britain’s new prime minister have fashion lovers in China talking. But feminist discussions about high heels are largely absent in the country.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Russia Announces Daily Cease-Fires to Allow Aid into Aleppo
item.media:description: Opposition fighters driving a tank in Aleppo’s rebel-held eastern portion, besieged by government forces for three weeks.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The Russian plan will halt “all military action, air and artillery strikes” in the Syrian city for three hours every day, allowing aid groups to enter the city.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: How Did People Migrate to the Americas? Bison DNA Helps Chart the Way
item.media:description: One research team has examined layers of lake sediment in the ice-free corridor that was a migration route for humans thousands of years ago.
item.description: Two groups of experts generally agree when a gateway from Siberia to North America opened, but not on who used it first.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS WADE

item.title: Gay and Transgender Egyptians, Harassed and Entrapped, Are Driven Underground
item.media:description: A gay Egyptian lighting a cigarette in Cairo. Since 2013, at least 250 lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people have been arrested in a quiet crackdown that has shattered what had been an increasingly vibrant and visible community.
item.description: A quiet crackdown by the country’s morality police has shattered what had been an increasingly vibrant and visible community.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Safari Guide Accused of Killing Tourist in Masai Mara Reserve in Kenya
item.media:description: Tourists in the Masai Mara reserve in 2015, during the “Great Migration,” when an estimated 1.5 million wildebeests and zebras pass through.
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: After an argument broke out at a lodge, apparently over where people would sit, the guide is alleged to have sunk a pocketknife into a woman’s chest.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Chinese City Backs Down on Proposed Nuclear Fuel Plant After Protests
item.media:description: A model of a nuclear reactor on display at the stand for the China National Nuclear Corporation at an expo in Beijing last year. Across the country, the nuclear disaster in Fukushima, Japan, in 2011 has hardened public wariness of nuclear power.
item.description: Thousands had demonstrated against plans to build a reprocessing plant in Lianyungang, which said that it was suspending preliminary work.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Musicians in a Refugee Camp in France Record ‘The Calais Sessions’
item.media:description: Some of the musicians at the refugee camp called Jungle who produced “The Calais Sessions,” including the cellist Vanessa Lucas-Smith, center, of the London ensemble the Allegri Quartet.
item.description: Professional musicians and talented amateurs at the migrant camp in France teamed up for a benefit world music project.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Sinosphere: Ai Weiwei’s Animal Heads Offer Critique of Chinese Nationalism
item.media:description: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei posing next to a sculpture from Circle of Animals/Zodiac Heads, one of a set of 12 bronze animals inspired by figures looted from the Old Summer Palace in Beijing in the 19th century.
item.media:credit: Hans Klaus Techt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The heads, on display at Princeton University, are replicas of zodiac heads once at the Old Summer Palace and are a commentary on historical memory.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Russia Allows Rare Protest Against New Antiterrorism Laws
item.media:description: Alexey Navalny, an opposition figure, addressed protesters in Moscow on Tuesday. “Freedom does not come for free,” he said.
item.description: Hundreds of critics, including opposition leaders, gathered in Moscow to criticize “intrusive measures” by the government against internet freedom.
item.dc:creator: LINCOLN PIGMAN

item.title: German Police Detain Asylum-Seeker Suspected of Plotting Terrorist Attack
item.description: The authorities received a tip that the man, a Syrian, was planning an attack later this month, intensifying fears about Islamic extremism and migrants.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: How a Chinese Man Hoping to Tour Europe Fell Into Germany’s Refugee System
item.description: The man, who apparently traveled to Europe alone speaking only Mandarin, was swept up into Germany’s vast processing system for two weeks.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Russia and Turkey Vow to Repair Ties as West Watches Nervously
item.description: The symbolism of a meeting in St. Petersburg between the Russian and Turkish presidents was probably enough to raise alarms in Western capitals.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: San Giovanni d'Asso Journal: A Merger of Brunello and Truffles? 2 Tuscan Towns May Be Better Together
item.media:description: A fort atop the Italian town of Montalcino. In October, residents there and in neighboring San Giovanni d’Asso will vote on whether to merge the two communities.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Montalcino, famous for red wine, and San Giovanni d’Asso, known for truffles, may join forces to provide better services, but there are worries about loss of local identity.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Indian Activist, Irom Chanu Sharmila, Ends Nearly 16-Year Hunger Strike
item.description: Ms. Sharmila had been force-fed through a tube in her nose while protesting a law shielding members of the military from prosecution. She now plans to run for office.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and HARI KUMAR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Israel Accuses U.N. Worker of Aiding Hamas in Gaza
item.media:description: The United Nations Development Program headquarters in Gaza City. One of its engineers has been detained by Israel’s internal security agency.
item.description: Prosecutors say a United Nations Development Program engineer used his position to provide material assistance to the Islamist group and its military wing.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Letter From Europe: Restoring Old Churches Inspires a New Philanthropy in Russia
item.media:description: The Orthodox Church of the Nativity in Trubetskoye, Russia, which is being restored with funds raised in charity events held by volunteers.
item.description: Private giving is in its infancy in a country with a history of state control, but church buildings arouse the volunteer spirit.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: ‘The Girl From Ipanema’ Goes Walking Again, With Gisele Bündchen’s Help
item.media:description: Heloísa Pinheiro in 2012. She was the muse for “The Girl From Ipanema.”
item.description: Thanks to the supermodel’s strut during the opening ceremony of the Rio Olympics, the 1963 bossa nova tune has found new life.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: What in the World: Who’s Got a Carrier to Rival the U.S. Navy’s? (Hint: Not Russia.)
item.media:description: The French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle has played a central role in carrying out airstrikes against the Islamic State in the Middle East.
item.description: To project striking power almost anywhere, it’s hard to beat a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier. Almost all of the 11 in existence are American — almost.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Saudi-Led Coalition Resumes Bombing of Yemeni Capital After Talks Collapse
item.description: Warplanes struck Sana, killing civilians, after the collapse of talks between Houthi rebels and the Saudi-backed government.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: ‘They Will Kill Us’: Afghan Translators Plead for Delayed U.S. Visas
item.media:description: Zar Mohammad Stanikzai at a relative’s home in Afghanistan. He is waiting for one of the thousands of visas set aside for the translators and interpreters who helped the United States military during the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.description: Translators, now facing Taliban threats, said the United States promised to keep them safe. Congress is bickering over the program meant to be their deliverance.
item.dc:creator: EMMARIE HUETTEMAN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Interpreter: In Japan, an Emperor Constrained by History and a National Identity Crisis
item.media:description: Emperor Akihito of Japan, right, with Tadamori Oshima, speaker of the lower house of Parliament, in Tokyo this month.
item.description: Since his reign began in 1989, Emperor Akihito has often embodied Japan’s contradiction: a pacifist nation and an imperial past.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: New Photos Cast Doubt on China’s Vow Not to Militarize Disputed Islands
item.description: Satellite imagery shows China has been building reinforced hangars on the disputed Spratly Islands that can easily accommodate warplanes.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Britain’s Paper Tigers
item.media:description: Hot off the press along Fleet Street, London, in May, 1940, delivering news of the growing German occupation in France.
item.description: The once mighty newspapers of Fleet Street still aim for sound and fury, but what do they signify?
item.dc:creator: STIG ABELL

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: These Days of Rage
item.media:description: Police tape outlined the scene in Ansbach, in southern Germany, where a man blew himself up last month.
item.description: The real terror of today’s terrorism is that it is so mindless and random, without political object.
item.dc:creator: KENAN MALIK
item.category: Dallas, Tex, Shooting of Police Officers (2016)

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Seismic Shock for Jacob Zuma
item.media:description: Residents of Diepsloot township, north of Johannesburg, line up to cast their votes last week in local government elections across South Africa.
item.description: The poor showing of his African National Congress party in local elections represents a political earthquake in South Africa.
item.dc:creator: MARK GEVISSER

item.title: Afghanistan Is in Chaos. Is That What Hamid Karzai Wants?
item.media:description: Hamid Karzai, the former president of Afghanistan, at his compound in Kabul last month.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Critics say the former president is working from the wings to destabilize his successor’s government. He says he has no interest in returning to power.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
